titleStmt.title: Walters Ms. W.494, Lace Book of Marie de' Medici
Added Flemish image cycle
Priers Crestiennes

title.note: This is the title inscribed on fol. 3r

titleStmt.title: Prayerbook

respStmt.name: Walters Art Museum curatorial staff and researchers since 1934

availability.p: Licensed for use under Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported Access Rights, http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/legalcode. It is requested that copies of any published articles based on the information in this data set be sent to the curator of manuscripts, The Walters Art Museum, 600 North Charles Street, Baltimore MD 21201.

notesStmt.note: This Prayerbook was made for Marie de' Medici in the second quarter of the seventeenth century. Beyond its provenance as a personal book owned by the famous queen, it is exceptional for its intricately cut borders, which transform the parchment margins into lace. This effect was created using a technique known as "canivet," in which a small knife was used to cut ornate patterns into paper or parchment. An art form that flourished originally among nuns in France, Germany, and the Netherlands beginning in the sixteenth century, it was employed to exceptional effect in several manuscripts connected with Marie de' Medici. The Walters manuscript, made for her while she was regent of France, and wife of King Henry IV, contains twenty-eight miniatures, including original religious imagery as well as several later additions: a gouache portrait of the elderly queen, and nine small miniatures produced in Bruges ca. 1450 by an artist influenced by the Eyckian and Gold Scrolls styles prevalent at the time; the coat-of-arms of Marie de Medici, as well as her monogram. The Walters manuscript retains its original binding composed of mosaic inlays in green and black leather, as well as fine gilt pointillé foliate tooling, and a replica of the binding was created by Léon Gruel for Henry Walters on one of his seventeenth-century printed books (92.467) that also connects to Marie de' Medici.

msContents.textLang: The primary language in this manuscript is French.

msItem.title: Added Flemish image cycle
msItem.note: Nine miniatures excised from earlier Book of Hours and inserted at later date

msItem.title: Priers Crestiennes

title.note: This is the title inscribed on fol. 3r

msItem.note: French prayers, mostly written in verse, focused especially on lamenting personal suffering

support.p: Medium-weight parchment, borders pierced with complex lace patterns; first flyleaf parchment; front flyleaves i-iv and back flyleaves i-iii are antique laid paper

supportDesc.foliation: Modern pencil foliation upper right corners rectos

p.formula: Lace-cut folios and fragile pigments make determining collation an unnecessary risk for manuscript

layoutDesc.layout: Layout varies greatly by page; text panels outlined in purple

decoDesc.decoNote: These miniatures date to ca. 1450, and were produced in Bruges by an artist influenced by the Eyckian and Gold Scrolls styles prevalent at the time; Randall has reconstructed the original textual sequence associated with these fifteenth-century Flemish miniatures, which have been inserted into the manuscript: fol. 1r, top: Funeral Service (Office of the Dead), and Annunciation (Hours of the Virgin: Matins); fol. 1r, bottom: Garden of Gethsemane (Hours of the Cross: Matins), and Betrayal and Arrest of Christ (Hours of the Cross: Lauds); fol. 2r, top: Christ before Pilate (Hours of the Cross: Prime), and Carrying the Cross (Hours of the Cross: Sext); fol. 2r, bottom: Man of Sorrows (Seven Prayers of St. Gregory), and Souls of the blessed before God the Father (Commendation of Souls); fol. 4r: St. Jerome in his study (Psalter of St. Jerome)
Miniatures (not including added cutting on fol. 4r) found on fols. 3r, 6r, 8r, 13r, 18r, 24r, 27r, 30r, 33r, 34r, 34v, 36r, 39r, 42r, 44r, 46r, 48r, 50v, and 51r

Nine miniatures, cuttings from a fifteenth-century Flemish Book of Hours, affixed to fols. 1r, 2r, and 4r; contemporary with the manuscript are also one full-page miniature, fifteen smaller miniatures, and illuminations or painted scenes or patterns in borders (passim); gouache portrait of elderly Marie de' Medici affixed to fol. 51r at uncertain point (painting dates to seventeenth or eighteenth century); borders of fols. 5-50 cut with intricate lace designs, often with painted imagery and designs including architectural elements, christological symbolism, ciphers, and anagrams, such as MA, MR, MH, CS, IHS, and MARIE DE MEDICIS (latter found on fols. 15r and 38r); initials in red, blue, gold, and silver; text in black ink

decoNote.title: Top: Funeral Service; Annunciation; Bottom: Garden of Gethsemane; Betrayal and Arrest of Christ

note.p: These miniatures were removed from their original context in a fifteenth-century Flemish Book of Hours and pasted into Marie de' Medici's book at an unknown time.

decoNote.title: Top: Christ before Pilate; Carrying the Cross; Bottom: Man of Sorrows supported by angel; Souls of the blessed brought before God the Father

note.p: These miniatures were removed from their original context in a fifteenth-century Flemish Book of Hours and pasted into Marie de' Medici's book at an unknown time.
This miniature was removed from its original context in a fifteenth-century Flemish Book of Hours and pasted into Marie de' Medici's book at an unknown time.

decoNote.title: Christ announcing Virgin's death to her; Assumption of Virgin in margin
Painted emblem with snakes, cross, oil lamp, and thistles on top of tomb

note.p: Painted in gouache on paper and affixed at later date.

binding.p: Bound in France, likely in Paris, by Ruette at time of manuscript's creation ca. 1640; red leather with olive-brown inlaid leather geometric panel designs; fine gilt pointillé foliate tooling; two extant gilt inlaid diamonds on spine; gilt edges; León Gruel created facsimile of binding for one of Henry Walters' related printed books, L'Entree de la Reyne Mere du Roy Tres-Chrestien dans les Villes des Pays Bas, 1632, by Jean Puget de La Serre (accession number 92.467)

origin.origDate: Second quarter of the 17th century (with several added 15th-century miniatures)

history.provenance: Created in Paris (?) for Marie de Medici in the second quarter of the seventeenth century

Baron d'Heiss, Paris, second half of the eighteenth century; related inscriptions: "o Ep" on front flyleaf i, r; "40D168. 1776" on back flyleaf i, r; sold in his sale in Paris on March 7, 1785, lot no. 358, with front flyleaf iii, r inscribed "No. 358. B. d'Heiss"
Duchesse de Berry, nineteenth century; inscribed "Duchesse de Berry No. 15" on front flyleaf i, r; her sale in Paris on March 22, 1864, lot no. 3, with "3" inscribed on front flyleaf i, r
M. de Machy, purchased from Berry sale in 1864 for 1,260 francs

León Gruel (?), late nineteenth or early twentieth century; his ownership of manuscript assumed given his careful replication of the binding on a printed book for Henry Walters ca. 1920, however there is no evidence in the manuscript to connect it with Gruel (he usually applied his bookplate inside), and as Walters owned the lace book by 1905, it is possible he obtained it elsewhere and only asked Gruel to replicate the binding; French book dealer Damascene Morgand published the lace book in 1886 while it was still in Machy's collection, and it is possible it could have gone through his hands later, as Walters purchased many books from him as well
Henry Walters, Baltimore, possibly acquired from Gruel or Morgand before 1905 when it is published by Gruel as a book owned by Walters
history.acquisition: Walters Art Museum, 1931, by Henry Walters' bequest
